quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: It's a terrible outcome to wake up one day and be late career and feel trapped because you have a certain lifestyle or a certain expectations of the people around you that you have to go work this job, but then you look at yourself in the mirror and you're not happy going in there.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Highlights the late-career risk of becoming locked into a job by lifestyle and external expectations despite personal dissatisfaction.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I think that's a terrible trap that we should all try to avoid as we navigate our career paths and find the thing that's most optimal for us.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Frames career navigation as an active effort to avoid a common trap and optimize intentionally rather than drift.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Which is usually a mix of career success, but also meaningfulness and alignment in the work that we're doing with our values.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Offers a practical decision criterion: optimize for both success and values-aligned meaningful work.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, it explains how to make better decisions with a framework she calls Curiosity Loops.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces a named decision-making framework that listeners can apply later in the episode.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We do a live exercise around my own personal values.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Signals a concrete, repeatable method—values exercises—to clarify alignment and guide career decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Sprig templates library
quotes.text: Sprig let's product teams collect user insights fast, allowing you to better understand why users take certain actions and how they feel about the experience.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical approach—rapid in-app insight collection—to diagnose user behavior and sentiment.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Sprig templates library
quotes.text: Sprig partnered with some of the top product teams and product thinkers to build proven playbooks, specifically to solve the biggest challenges facing product teams today from how to optimize an existing feature to improving a conversion flow to troubleshooting drop off.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Offers a reusable playbook methodology for common product problems (optimization, conversion, drop-off).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Sprig templates library
quotes.text: Sprig now has a library of more than 85 templates that you can use to get started collecting user insights quickly right in your app.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete data point and an actionable starting point for implementing in-app research quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Sprig templates library
quotes.text: One of the questions they get most is how to develop your product sense.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Surfaces a key practitioner development area—building product sense—as a common, high-demand skill gap.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Sprig templates library
quotes.text: So I decided to build a playbook along with Sprig on how to do that based on my experience at Airbnb and from what I've learned interviewing top product folks like, Jules Walter who wrote a whole guest post on how to build your product sense.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Describes a learnable methodology for product sense: codify experience + synthesize insights from top practitioners into a playbook.

quotes.topic_title: Curiosity Loops: structured advice gathering
quotes.text: So in this case, a question's good if it's specific, if it solicits rationale, and it's not biased.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A crisp rubric practitioners can use to craft higher-quality questions that yield better advice.

quotes.topic_title: Curiosity Loops: structured advice gathering
quotes.text: A bad example of a question is, what should I do with my career next? It's just such a poorly formed question because it's really vague, it's not specific. It puts a lot of cognitive load on other people, and the output that you're going to get from it is probably going to be similarly bad. Garbage in, garbage out.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Explains why generic advice-asking fails and ties question quality directly to response quality and effort required.

quotes.topic_title: Curiosity Loops: structured advice gathering
quotes.text: The next piece is really around how do you curate who you ask? I think there are two dimensions of this. The first one is the obvious one, which is a subject matter expert who really knows something about the topic at hand. So maybe a webdev themselves, for my example question. Another one, and this dimension I think is really important, is someone who knows you really well and can provide insight on how well does that work for you.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A practical selection framework: balance domain expertise with personal context to make advice actually applicable.

quotes.topic_title: Curiosity Loops: structured advice gathering
quotes.text: Ask the question in a way that really gets you a useful constructive answer, but doesn't put too much weight on people.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A reminder to design for low respondent effort to improve response rates and answer quality.

quotes.topic_title: Curiosity Loops: structured advice gathering
quotes.text: I'm asking you for help and you're getting nothing out of it. The reminder that I would have for all of you is that it feels really good to help someone. It feels really good to be heard and give input.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Counteracts the fear of “bothering people” by reframing advice requests as mutually rewarding when closed with gratitude.

quotes.topic_title: Curiosity Loops in personal life decisions
quotes.text: I would try to optimize for getting at least three or four responses. It just depends on the nature of the loop. And then you think about what is your response rate.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for designing a “curiosity loop” by targeting a minimum number of responses and planning outreach volume based on expected reply rate.

quotes.topic_title: Curiosity Loops in personal life decisions
quotes.text: But we wouldn't have figured that out without a curiosity loop because it's too much work to dig through papers or research or whatever else to try to come to a good decision on it.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Highlights the curiosity loop as a practical methodology for surfacing key insights you wouldn’t realistically uncover via solo research.

quotes.topic_title: Curiosity Loops in personal life decisions
quotes.text: One of the things that I always try to do is I try to explain to people in my ask, here's why I picked you.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A simple tactic to increase response quality and willingness to help by explicitly stating why the person is a trusted advisor.

quotes.topic_title: Curiosity Loops in personal life decisions
quotes.text: I think this is really based off of the marketing concept of customer advisory councils.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Connects the personal “curiosity loop” to a proven business practice, offering a transferable mental model for decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Curiosity Loops in personal life decisions
quotes.text: Don't do what people tell you to do. Take it as an input and look for the hard feedback. Look for things that you strongly disagree with or are surprises to you.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder that advice-seeking is most valuable for uncovering blind spots and disagreement, not for outsourcing the decision.

quotes.topic_title: Topic selection feedback and “no winning” topics
quotes.text: And the feedback I got there was like, "There's just so many people who have done this. I'm sure you have some interesting concepts, but I personally wouldn't be that interested in hearing it. And that was really useful to me."
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A practical reminder to use audience feedback to avoid over-covered topics even if you have something to add.

quotes.topic_title: Topic selection feedback and “no winning” topics
quotes.text: "No. Stay far away from this. There's no winning on this topic."
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Captures the reputational/interpretation risk of certain topics and the idea that some discussions can be lose-lose regardless of intent.

quotes.topic_title: Topic selection feedback and “no winning” topics
quotes.text: Oh, my God. Okay, let's touch on that topic rather than, it's going to be great.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A counterintuitive editorial choice: leaning into the “avoid” topic can be compelling and valuable for the audience.

quotes.topic_title: Values exercise: building an internal scorecard
quotes.text: So the homework that I gave you is similar homework that I give to everyone that I work with in coaching, and it's this values exercise. It's this 10 to 15 minute exercise where you're presented with a list of words that might encompass potential values.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A practical, time-bounded method for quickly identifying personal values without overthinking from scratch.

quotes.topic_title: Values exercise: building an internal scorecard
quotes.text: And what I really like is, it's this internal scorecard of what really matters to you in your decision making process as opposed to the external scorecard of status, money, wealth, how other people perceive you, that often we feel really pressured by.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A memorable mental model contrasting internal values-based evaluation with external status metrics that commonly drive decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Values exercise: building an internal scorecard
quotes.text: So it's this great way to look back and see how well do decisions, or how well do my situations in life align with my values?
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Turns values into an actionable retrospective tool for assessing decision quality and life/job fit.

quotes.topic_title: Values exercise: building an internal scorecard
quotes.text: And what I liked about it is, if someone were to be like, "Hey, come up with your values." I'd be like, "Oh, my God. I'm just sitting here thinking about words and concepts." And it was really helpful because it was basically multiple choice.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a simple design principle—use constrained choices—to make abstract self-reflection exercises easier to complete.

quotes.topic_title: Values exercise: building an internal scorecard
quotes.text: What a great list of values and what stands out to me from that list too, Lenny, is this idea of achievement or status or success. A lot of the things that we talk about publicly, what your LinkedIn feed might look like don't actually show up in your values.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A contrarian observation that public-facing success signals often don’t match what people truly prioritize internally.

quotes.topic_title: Applying values to Lenny’s “say yes/no” dilemma
quotes.text: Yeah. Yeah. And then maybe if you were to decompose adventure, what adventure actually means to you and you go into that word list, you might actually just find that some of these opportunities like writing a book, at some point, it doesn't feel like an adventure.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A practical values-clarification method: break down a value into its components to test whether a commitment still aligns over time.

quotes.topic_title: Applying values to Lenny’s “say yes/no” dilemma
quotes.text: Something I always say about this content creation life is like, it's easy to start. It's hard to keep it going, and it becomes just this treadmill of just, you have to keep creating awesome stuff basically for the rest of your life.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable warning about recurring-commitment “treadmills” that helps evaluate the true long-term cost of saying yes.

quotes.topic_title: Applying values to Lenny’s “say yes/no” dilemma
quotes.text: So I think values are this really nice useful tool to think about how do you make better decisions again to maximize for your own alignment with life.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A decision-making lens: use values not to optimize for external outcomes, but for personal alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Applying values to Lenny’s “say yes/no” dilemma
quotes.text: I have all these auto templates of ways to say no in different ways.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete tactic practitioners can copy: pre-write “no” templates to make declining requests easier and more consistent.

quotes.topic_title: Applying values to Lenny’s “say yes/no” dilemma
quotes.text: I think you could definitely use that process to force yourself to make a stack ring and to be really clear, and also change it. Change it. It's yours. So change it over time as it suits you.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A methodology for iterating on values: treat them as an evolving “stack rank” you can update as life circumstances change.

quotes.topic_title: Early career strategy: explore vs exploit
quotes.text: And when I reflect back on what works across my early career, it really comes down in a nutshell to this career concept of explore and exploit, which actually sounds dark now that I'm saying it out loud, but-
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable career strategy framework that anchors the rest of her early-career decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Early career strategy: explore vs exploit
quotes.text: You're either in a mode of explorer where you have a bunch of unknowns and you're testing to see whether or not you like it, how well it works, whether or not it fits for you. Or you're exploiting, where you actually have found something that's really rich and really deep and then you're just trying to get more.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Defines the two modes in a way practitioners can use to diagnose what they should optimize for right now.

quotes.topic_title: Early career strategy: explore vs exploit
quotes.text: And when I think about explore and exploit for early career, it's all about exploration. You really haven't experienced that much, but you're doing it with a thesis. You're doing it with that growth mindset where you have a hypothesis.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Turns “try lots of things” into an actionable method: explore deliberately with hypotheses rather than random job-hopping.

quotes.topic_title: Early career strategy: explore vs exploit
quotes.text: So unlike a traditional path where you're really focused on trying to get the biggest title, a big team, set yourself up to run a big org, my role at LinkedIn was really explicit. I even told my manager this when I first came in, "I'm here to learn to be a better founder."
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A contrarian career move: optimize for learning goals over title/compensation, and communicate that explicitly to shape your role.

quotes.topic_title: Early career strategy: explore vs exploit
quotes.text: Over the course of seven years, I went from my first job, which was basically this entry level sales job at Microsoft, working on Microsoft adCenter to SVP of marketing at SurveyMonkey, leading a global team.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A concrete data point illustrating the potential upside of the explore-then-exploit approach when executed intentionally.

quotes.topic_title: When to stick it out vs leave a job
quotes.text: So one of the things that I like to share is this idea of, it's a little gory, don't be the frog.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable mental model for noticing gradual deterioration and complacency in a job.

quotes.topic_title: When to stick it out vs leave a job
quotes.text: But you really have to be aware of your surroundings. You have to be aware of which way is the direction of the temperature of the water trending.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to monitor whether your situation is improving or worsening over time rather than judging a single moment.

quotes.topic_title: When to stick it out vs leave a job
quotes.text: I really look at it from the lens of learning. What can I learn here, and how am I growing and developing?
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Provides a practical decision criterion—learning and growth—as the core heuristic for stay vs leave.

quotes.topic_title: When to stick it out vs leave a job
quotes.text: And it doesn't necessarily mean that the strategy is to quit your job and do something catastrophic, and then go do something else, take a course or sign up for something new. It might actually mean a proactive conversation with your manager or the leadership to say, "I love what I'm doing here, and I would also like to learn a little bit more. And here's what I'm interested in."
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Counterbalances the default “just quit” impulse with a lower-risk intervention: explicitly negotiating for growth.

quotes.topic_title: When to stick it out vs leave a job
quotes.text: Let's say, you hit a blank wall there, even take it as a gift of time, which is great. I'm not going to be able to get this from my company, but now that I have this extra time because I'm so optimized at this job, how am I going to choose to use that time?
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Reframes stalled growth as an opportunity to invest surplus capacity into relationships or skill-building for the next step.

quotes.topic_title: Resume optimization vs meaningful work alignment
quotes.text: Keep an eye on your environment and which way is it trending?
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A simple ongoing check to notice gradual deterioration (the “boiling frog” effect) before you get stuck.

quotes.topic_title: Resume optimization vs meaningful work alignment
quotes.text: Life is that resume. Right? That is your life, you're living, and there's not going to be a point at which you have to realize, okay, I've done all the things to make my resume.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that challenges the endless optimization loop of chasing titles/logos over lived experience.

quotes.topic_title: Resume optimization vs meaningful work alignment
quotes.text: I looked at those values and I said, "Well, if I draw a straight line from where I am right now and just extend it forward and play the rest of the movie as it plays out, given the current plot line, how well does that optimize for those values?"
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A practical mental model: project your current trajectory forward and evaluate it against your stated values.

quotes.topic_title: Resume optimization vs meaningful work alignment
quotes.text: So getting very intentional about that and being clear about who your audience is as you navigate your career.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to explicitly decide whose approval you’re optimizing for in career decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Resume optimization vs meaningful work alignment
quotes.text: I think it's a terrible outcome to wake up one day and be late career and feel trapped because you have a certain lifestyle or a certain expectations of the people around you that you have to go work this job, but then you look at yourself in the mirror and you're not happy going in there.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A cautionary example of how external expectations and lifestyle creep can create long-term career misalignment.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Sprig templates (repeat)
quotes.text: What triggered your reevaluation of that path?
quotes.speaker: Interviewer
quotes.context: A diagnostic prompt practitioners can use to pinpoint the catalyst behind a career or strategy reassessment.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Sprig templates (repeat)
quotes.text: Was there just like a, "Oh, man. I need to really rethink where I'm going."
quotes.speaker: Interviewer
quotes.context: Captures the recognizable inflection-point moment that can signal it’s time to step back and reassess direction.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Sprig templates (repeat)
quotes.text: And then I have a follow-up question.
quotes.speaker: Interviewer
quotes.context: Highlights the importance of not stopping at the initial trigger and instead probing deeper with structured follow-ups.

quotes.topic_title: Trigger for reevaluating career: values vs prestige
quotes.text: Ada, go through and fill out this values exercise, and apply it to this job.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable tactic: use a values exercise as a decision filter for evaluating a role.

quotes.topic_title: Trigger for reevaluating career: values vs prestige
quotes.text: What I realized at the time, after I did it, was that my top three values, the things that I cared about this job would categorically just fail at because I would be gone all the time, in pursuit of glory that I didn't really care about.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A vivid example of how prestige can mask a values mismatch—and how to diagnose it by checking your top values against the job’s realities.

quotes.topic_title: Trigger for reevaluating career: values vs prestige
quotes.text: Okay, that's the ego monster pulling at me. I don't have to listen to that. Doesn't mean I'm going to be happy if I listen to this guy.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for separating ego-driven impulses from what will actually make you happy.

quotes.topic_title: Trigger for reevaluating career: values vs prestige
quotes.text: I use something that Warren Buffet has talked about, which is inner scorecard versus outer scorecard.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A simple framework for evaluating career choices by internal values vs external validation.

quotes.topic_title: Trigger for reevaluating career: values vs prestige
quotes.text: So really thinking about did you win at the cost of kindness? Did you succeed at the cost of losing access to the adventure that you really wanted?
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A practical set of tradeoff questions to pressure-test “success” against what you value most.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching: who needs it and alternatives
quotes.text: But my hot take is that for the vast majority of people, they probably do not need a coach.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A contrarian baseline that challenges the default assumption that coaching is broadly necessary.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching: who needs it and alternatives
quotes.text: I ask them, "What are your goals when it comes to coaching? Roll it forward six months, what have you gotten done in your coaching experience. What have you accomplished, and you're just... It's like, a home run. And then look at all of the potential alternatives in terms of how you could have spent your valuable time and often pricey fees to achieve the same goal, but maybe in a better way."
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: A practical decision framework: define a 6-month “home run” outcome, then compare coaching against alternative investments of time and money.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching: who needs it and alternatives
quotes.text: The thing that people don't really think about is if you're looking for a mentor, a coach is actually a terrible mentor in some ways because it's this one person's opinion. It's actually way better to run a curiosity loop, for example, and get the benefit a couple different minds on a specific topic and hit their wheelhouse of things that they know about. Than to go ask one person, what do you think I should do in this situation?
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Reframes mentorship as a “curiosity loop” that samples multiple experts instead of relying on a single coach’s perspective.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching: who needs it and alternatives
quotes.text: Likewise, if you're just feeling like you're a little emotionally overcome, I think coaches are this great resource around that, but it's actually better to pay it forward and build a tribe and a community of people around you that you can rely on for support because that's the thing that lasts you for years and years.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Actionable alternative: prioritize durable community support over paid coaching for emotional resilience.

quotes.topic_title: Coaching: who needs it and alternatives
quotes.text: So when you have situations where you're in a state of hyper growth, and you need very accelerated learning, and you need someone who can point you in the right direction, I think coaches can be really helpful.
quotes.speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
quotes.context: Defines a clear condition where coaching is high-leverage: hyper-growth contexts requiring accelerated learning and direction.
